channel.title: How do you make PHP files?
channel.description:
I really need to know. Thank you guys (and girls) who can. Cos' i only know HTML and i would like to learn PHP. But i don't know where to start.
If you could write a tutorial explaining things, thanks.
~Time2Script

item.title: How do you make PHP files?
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

[quote=".Fusion, post:16, topic:100466"][quote author=kloplop321 link=topic=144206.msg1379711#msg1379711 date=1180226596]
he doesn’t know [that much, any] php, give him a break. That is just how you start a php script, exept without the “php?>” That is just wrong. Also, he is not a negro, he is from Australia(far from Africa!)!
[/quote]
idc your a negro too. pwnd is a sexy negro :D[/quote]

ohK… You really went off in the wrong direction with that!

[quote=“sppt, post:17, topic:100466”][quote author=kloplop321 link=topic=144206.msg1378244#msg1378244 date=1180209951]
[php]

<?php $stringy = "this is a simple string variable, the $ just means it is a variable and not a function or command."; $arrayThis[1] = "This is how you make arrays or data sets, the brackets '[' & ']' just means that what ever is inside it is the sub-variable that will come out."; $arrayThis[2] = "Therefore, Seriously, I do like arrays, and beans if you like,"; $html[1] = ""; $html[2] = ""; $html[3] = ""; $html[4] = "
"; $title = "Hello and welcome to variables and arrays"; //when you wish to add or combine things you use a "." like in some code "&" or "+" echo $html[1].$title.$html[2].$stringy.$html[4].$arrayThis[1].$html[4].$arrayThis[2].$html[3]; ?>

[/php]
[/quote]
i hope you realize that putting a number in the brackets when defining arrays isn’t needed, and they start at 0 ;)[/quote]

Ohh well. I just started with arrays(numbers, strings like [php]$cheese[“kind”] = “cheddar”;[/php] I have been doing for a while.)
It works though, and that is what matters.

Read full topic
item.source: How do you make PHP files?

<?php $stringy = "this is a simple string variable, the $ just means it is a variable and not a function or command."; $arrayThis[1] = "This is how you make arrays or data sets, the brackets '[' & ']' just means that what ever is inside it is the sub-variable that will come out."; $arrayThis[2] = "Therefore, Seriously, I do like arrays, and beans if you like,"; $html[1] = ""; $html[2] = ""; $html[3] = ""; $html[4] = "
"; $title = "Hello and welcome to variables and arrays"; //when you wish to add or combine things you use a "." like in some code "&" or "+" echo $html[1].$title.$html[2].$stringy.$html[4].$arrayThis[1].$html[4].$arrayThis[2].$html[3]; ?>

[/php][/quote]
i hope you realize that putting a number in the brackets when defining arrays isn’t needed, and they start at 0

You need to be friend’s with the stubborn syntax of php, it isn’t like html where the browser will automaticly fixes it for you.

item.title: How do you make PHP files?
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

you can test out your php using a WAMP server, or MAMP or LAMP depending on your OS
it is (Your Operating System’s first letter) Apache MySQL PHP server. and save your files in for example “C:/wamp/www/file.php” and go to “http://localhost/file.php”
http://www.wampserver.com/en/
http://www.howtoforge.com/lamp_installation_ubuntu6.06
http://www.mamp.info/en/index.php

here is another php example
[php]

<?php $stringy = "this is a simple string variable, the $ just means it is a variable and not a function or command."; $arrayThis[1] = "This is how you make arrays or data sets, the brackets '[' & ']' just means that what ever is inside it is the sub-variable that will come out."; $arrayThis[2] = "Therefore, Seriously, I do like arrays, and beans if you like,"; $html[1] = ""; $html[2] = ""; $html[3] = ""; $html[4] = "
"; $title = "Hello and welcome to variables and arrays"; //when you wish to add or combine things you use a "." like in some code "&" or "+" echo $html[1].$title.$html[2].$stringy.$html[4].$arrayThis[1].$html[4].$arrayThis[2].$html[3]; ?>

[/php]

[quote=“Pwnd, post:7, topic:100466”]http://w3schools.com/php/default.asp

Sex.[/quote]

don’t give this forum a bad atmosphere, especially to a newbie

Read full topic

item.title: How do you make PHP files?
item.dc:creator: @kloplop321 kloplop321
item.description:
@kloplop321 wrote:

I refer to the official php website a little, but the most important step is that you name it like “file.php” you need the “.php” so for a beginers script try
[php]

<?php echo "Here is my website!"; //echo means it will pass on the text to the client(the person viewing) // the two "/"'s are comments, and after every individual command, you must end with ";" /* this does the same effect as "//" but you must end in */ //to end the multi-line comment. This helps if you just want to cut out something temporarily //but maybe refer to some of the coding in there. echo "

Well, thanks for visiting." ?>

[/php]

Read full topic
